dialogs.original: Why, so. Now have I done a good days work.    You peers, continue this united league.    I every day expect an embassage    From my Redeemer to redeem me hence,    And more in peace my soul shall part to heaven    Since I have made my friends at peace on earth    Rivers and Hastings, take each others hand.    Dissemble not your hatred. Swear your love.
dialogs.translated: Well, now I've done a good day's work. You must all maintain this unity and friendship. Every day I expect a messenger of God to bear me away from here, and I can leave for heaven in peace now that my friends have made their peace on earth. Rivers and Hastings, take each other's hand. Don't just hide your hatred under a facade of friendship. Swear your love for each other.

dialogs.original: [taking HASTINGSs hand]  By heaven, my soul is purged from grudging hate, And with my hand I seal my true hearts love.
dialogs.translated: [Taking HASTINGS' hand] By heaven, my soul is now cleansed of all grudges and hatred. With this handshake I swear that this love is true.

dialogs.original: So thrive I as I truly swear the like.
dialogs.translated: So may I prosper, as I swear the same thing.

dialogs.original: Take heed you dally not before your king,    Lest He that is the supreme King of kings    Confound your hidden falsehood, and award    Either of you to be the others end.
dialogs.translated: Make sure that you don't mock your king by lying in front of him. Otherwise God, the supreme King of Kings, will uncover your hidden lies and cause you to be the death of each other.

dialogs.original: So prosper I as I swear perfect love.
dialogs.translated: I swear perfect love for Rivers, or may I never prosper.

dialogs.original: And I as I love Hastings with my heart.
dialogs.translated: And I love Hastings with all my heart.

dialogs.original: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]     Madam, yourself is not exempt in this,    Nor you, son Dorset, Buckingham, nor you.    You have been factious one against the other.    Wife, love Lord Hastings. Let him kiss your hand,    And what you do, do it unfeignedly.
dialogs.translated: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] Madam, you're not exempt from this.

dialogs.original: There, Hastings, I will never more rememberOur former hatred, so thrive I and mine.
dialogs.translated: Here's my hand, Hastings. I will forget all our past hatred for each other, and may we both prosper in the future.

dialogs.original: Dorset, embrace him.Hastings, love Lord Marquess.
dialogs.translated: Now Dorset, hug Hastings. Hastings, befriend Lord Marquess of Dorset.

dialogs.original: This interchange of love, I here protest,Upon my part shall be inviolable.
dialogs.translated: I swear that I will never go back on this exchange of love and friendship.

dialogs.original: And so swear I.
dialogs.translated: And I swear it too.

dialogs.original: Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league With thy embracements to my wifes alliesAnd make me happy in your unity.
dialogs.translated: Now, princely Buckingham, seal this friendship by embracing my wife's allies, and through your unity make me happy.

dialogs.original: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]     Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate    Upon your Grace, but with all duteous love    Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me    With hate in those where I expect most love.    When I have most need to employ a friend,    And most assurèd that he is a friend,    Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile    Be he unto me:   this do I beg of God    When I am cold in love to you or yours.
dialogs.translated: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] If I should ever come to hate your Grace, and fail to love and cherish you and your relatives, may God punish me by making me find hatred where I expect love. When I most need a friend and am sure that my friends are trustworthy, may they turn false, treacherous, and full of deceit. I beg that God will do this if I ever lose my love for you and your allies.

dialogs.original: A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham,    Is this thy vow unto my sickly heart.    There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here    To make the blessèd period of this peace.
dialogs.translated: Noble Buckingham, your vow of friendship is like medicine for my sickly heart. Now all we need is my brother Richard to bring the blessed conclusion to this time of peace.

dialogs.original: And in good time,Here comes Sir Richard Ratcliffe and the duke.
dialogs.translated: And just in time, here comes Richard with Sir Richard Ratcliffe.

dialogs.original: Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen,And, princely peers, a happy time of day.
dialogs.translated: Good morning to my sovereign king and queen. And I'm happy to see you too, my princely peers.

dialogs.original: Happy indeed, as we have spent the day.    Brother, we have done deeds of charity,    Made peace of enmity, fair love of hate,    Between these swelling, wrong-incensèd peers.
dialogs.translated: Happy indeedthat's the way we've spent the day. Brother, we have done deeds of love, turning enmity to peace and hatred to love between these misguidedly angry nobles.

dialogs.original: A blessèd labor, my most sovereign lord.    Amongst this princely heap, if any here    By false intelligence, or wrong surmise    Hold me a foe,    If I unwittingly, or in my rage,    Have aught committed that is hardly borne    By any in this presence,   I desire    To reconcile me to his friendly peace.    'Tis death to me to be at enmity;    I hate it, and desire all good mens love.    First, madam, I entreat true peace of you,    Which I will purchase with my duteous service;    Of you, my noble cousin Buckingham,    If ever any grudge were lodged between us;    Of you, Lord Rivers, and Lord Gray of you,    Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen; indeed of all!    I do not know that Englishman alive    With whom my soul is any jot at odds    More than the infant that is born tonight.    I thank my God for my humility.
dialogs.translated: A blessed labor, my sovereign lord. If any among this princely group considers me an enemywhether from lies they've heard about me, or because by accident or in anger I've done something to give offenseI want us to be reconciled and become peaceful friends. To be enemies with anyone is like death to me; I hate it, and only desire the love of all good men.

dialogs.original: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter.    I would to God all strifes were well compounded.    My sovereign lord, I do beseech your Highness    To take our brother Clarence to your grace.
dialogs.translated: This will be remembered as a holy day. I wish to God that all troubles could end this well. But I must also ask your Highness to pardon your brother Clarence.

dialogs.original: Why, madam, have I offered love for this,To be so flouted in this royal presence? Who knows not that the gentle duke is dead?
dialogs.translated: Why, madam, have I offered you my love only to be mocked in front of the king? Who doesn't know that the gentle duke is dead?

dialogs.original: You do him injury to scorn his corse.
dialogs.translated: You do him wrong to joke about his death.

dialogs.original: Who knows not he is dead! Who knows he is?
dialogs.translated: Who doesn't know that he's dead? Who knew that he was!

dialogs.original: All-seeing heaven, what a world is this!
dialogs.translated: Oh all-seeing God, what a terrible world!

dialogs.original: Look I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?
dialogs.translated: Do I look as pale as everyone else, Lord Dorset?

dialogs.original: Ay, my good lord, and no one in the presenceBut his red color hath forsook his cheeks.
dialogs.translated: Yes, my good lord. Everyone here in the king's presence has gone totally pale.

dialogs.original: Is Clarence dead? The order was reversed.
dialogs.translated: Is Clarence dead? The death sentence had been reversed.

dialogs.original: But he, poor man, by your first order died,    And that a wingèd Mercury did bear.    Some tardy cripple bear the countermand,    That came too lag to see him burièd.    God grant that some, less noble and less loyal,    Nearer in bloody thoughts, and not in blood,    Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did,    And yet go current from suspicion.
dialogs.translated: But Clarence died by your first order, the poor man. The death sentence must have been carried by Mercury, the winged messenger god, while the counter-order was carried by some slow cripple. It arrived too late even for his burial. It seems that someone less noble and less loyalnearer in bloody thoughts but not a blood relationdeserves the punishment that poor Clarence got, but instead goes free without suspicion.

dialogs.original: [kneeling]  A boon, my sovereign, for my service done.
dialogs.translated: [Kneeling] I must ask you a favor in return for the service I've done for you, my king.

dialogs.original: I prithee, peace. My soul is full of sorrow.
dialogs.translated: Quiet, please. My soul is full of sorrow.

dialogs.original: I will not rise unless your Highness hear me.
dialogs.translated: I will not rise until your Highness hears my request.

dialogs.original: Then say at once what is it thou requests.
dialogs.translated: Then quickly say what it is you want.

dialogs.original: The forfeit, sovereign, of my servants life,Who slew today a riotous gentlemanLately attendant on the duke of Norfolk.
dialogs.translated: I ask you to spare the life of my servant, who just today killed a rowdy gentleman that used to serve the Duke of Norfolk.

dialogs.original: Have I a tongue to doom my brothers death,    And shall the tongue give pardon to a slave?    My brother killed no man; his fault was thought,    And yet his punishment was bitter death.    Who sued to me for him? Who, in my wrath,    Kneeled at my feet, and bade me be advised?    Who spoke of brotherhood? Who spoke of love?    Who told me how the poor soul did forsake    The mighty Warwick and did fight for me?    Who told me, in the field by Tewkesbury,    When Oxford had me down, he rescued me,    And said Dear brother, live, and be a king?    Who told me, when we both lay in the field    Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me    Even in his garments and did give himself,    All thin and naked, to the numb-cold night?    All this from my remembrance brutish wrath    Sinfully plucked, and not a man of you    Had so much grace to put it in my mind.    But when your carters or your waiting vassals    Have done a drunken slaughter and defaced    The precious image of our dear Redeemer,    You straight are on your knees for pardon, pardon,    And I, unjustly too, must grant it you.     [STANLEY rises]     But for my brother, not a man would speak,    Nor I, ungracious, speak unto myself    For him, poor soul.   The proudest of you all    Have been beholding to him in his life,    Yet none of you would once beg for his life.    O God, I fear Thy justice will take hold    On me and you, and mine and yours for this!    Come, Hastings, help me to my closet.    Ah, poor Clarence.
dialogs.translated: I was willing to condemn my own brother to death, and now you want me to pardon a servant? My brother Clarence didn't kill anyone. His only fault was his ideas, and yet he was punished with bitter death. Who pled on his behalf?  When I was so angry, who kneeled at my feet and asked me to think about what I was doing? Who spoke to me about brotherhood? Who spoke about love? Who told me how the poor soul abandoned his father-in-lawthe mighty Earl of Warwickto come fight for me? Who told me of the battlefield at Tewkesbury, where Clarence rescued me when Oxford had me down, saying, "Dear brother, live, and be a king?" Who told me how, when we both lay in the field almost freezing to death, he wrapped me in his own clothes and left himself naked, exposed to the mercy of the numbingly cold night? All this seemed erased from my memory in my brutish rage, and not a man of you had the grace to remind me. But when your servants drunkenly kill someone and scorn the law of our dear Christ, you immediately get on your knees and beg, "pardon, pardon." And I, unfair as I am, must give it to you. [Stanley rises] But no one spoke on behalf my brother, and I didn't speak to myself on his behalf either, the poor soul. Even the proudest among you owed him something, and yet none of you would beg for his life. Oh God, I fear that your justice will punish me and all these gathered here, and our families as well, because of this!

dialogs.original: This is the fruits of rashness. Marked you not    How that the guilty kindred of the queen    Looked pale when they did hear of Clarence' death?    O, they did urge it still unto the king.    God will revenge it.   Come, lords, will you go    To comfort Edward with our company?
dialogs.translated: This sorrow is the result of recklessness. Didn't you notice how the queen's guilty relatives turned pale when they heard about Clarence's death? Oh, they were always urging the king to do it. God will revenge it. Come, lords, will you come with me to comfort Edward with our companionship?

dialogs.original: We wait upon your Grace.
dialogs.translated: We will attend you, your Grace.
